Pepper_Bell_Bacterial_spot.Description: Caused by Xanthomonas campestris, bacterial spot appears as water-soaked lesions on leaves, which turn brown and become rough over time. Severe infections can cause leaf drop and blemishes on fruits.
Pepper_Bell_Bacterial_spot.Solution: Use copper-based fungicides and avoid overhead watering to prevent the spread of bacteria. Remove infected plants and avoid working with plants when they are wet. Use disease-free seeds and resistant varieties.

Pepper_bell_healthy.Description: A healthy pepper plant has dark green leaves, no signs of lesions, or leaf spots, and grows strong stems with vibrant fruits.
Pepper_bell_healthy.Solution: Maintain optimal soil moisture, well-draining soil, and avoid excessive nitrogen to prevent excessive foliage.

Potato_Early_blight.Description: Early blight, caused by Alternaria solani, produces dark, concentric spots on leaves, typically affecting older leaves first. This can reduce yield if left unchecked.
Potato_Early_blight.Solution: Use fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper. Remove affected foliage and rotate crops to prevent soil buildup of the pathogen.

Potato_healthy.Description: A healthy potato plant shows consistent green foliage without spots, blemishes, or wilting, and tubers are firm and undamaged.
Potato_healthy.Solution: Ensure proper spacing, avoid overwatering, and practice crop rotation to prevent disease buildup in the soil.

Potato_Late_blight.Description: Caused by Phytophthora infestans, late blight causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, eventually leading to plant collapse. Tubers may also rot.
Potato_Late_blight.Solution: Apply fungicides like mancozeb or chlorothalonil as preventative measures. Remove infected plants and avoid overhead watering. Rotate crops yearly.

Tomato_Target_Spot.Description: Target spot, caused by Corynespora cassiicola, presents as small brown lesions on leaves, which expand and may cause defoliation.
Tomato_Target_Spot.Solution: Use fungicides and ensure good air circulation around plants. Remove infected foliage and avoid wetting leaves during irrigation.

Tomato_mosaic_virus.Description: The mosaic virus causes mottled or stunted growth and deformed fruits. It spreads through contaminated tools, insects, or direct contact.
Tomato_mosaic_virus.Solution: Use virus-resistant varieties and sanitize tools. Control aphids and other pests that may carry the virus.

Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.Description: This virus is spread by whiteflies and causes yellowing, curling, and stunted growth in tomato plants.
Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.Solution: Control whiteflies using insecticidal soap or neem oil. Use resistant varieties and cover plants with fine netting if necessary.

Tomato_Bacterial_spot.Description: Similar to pepper bacterial spot, this is caused by Xanthomonas, leading to dark, water-soaked spots on leaves and stems.
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.Solution: Use copper-based fungicides and remove infected leaves. Practice crop rotation and avoid working with wet plants.

Tomato_Early_blight.Description: Early blight in tomatoes causes dark spots with concentric rings, usually affecting older foliage first.
Tomato_Early_blight.Solution: Use fungicides and practice good crop rotation. Remove affected leaves and ensure adequate plant spacing.

Tomato_healthy.Description: A healthy tomato plant has firm, green leaves without spots or discoloration, and bears strong, vibrant fruits.
Tomato_healthy.Solution: Provide balanced nutrition, proper watering, and regular pruning to encourage healthy growth.

Tomato_Late_blight.Description: Late blight leads to dark lesions on leaves and stems, eventually causing plant collapse. Fruits develop brown rot.
Tomato_Late_blight.Solution: Use fungicides preventatively, especially in damp conditions. Remove infected plants promptly and avoid overhead watering.

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.Description: Leaf mold causes yellow spots on leaves, turning brown and fuzzy on the underside.
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.Solution: Improve ventilation, avoid overhead watering, and apply appropriate fungicides to control spread.

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.Description: Small, circular spots with dark borders appear on leaves, causing premature leaf drop.
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.Solution: Use fungicides and remove affected leaves. Ensure good air circulation and avoid wetting foliage.

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.Description: Spider mites cause tiny yellow spots on leaves and fine webbing, leading to a stippled or faded appearance.
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.Solution: Spray with insecticidal soap or neem oil. Increase humidity to deter mites, as they thrive in dry conditions.
